newsitem.title: USA: Compuware CEO mulls adding jobs in Conneticut. - paper.
newsitem.headline: Compuware CEO mulls adding jobs in Conneticut. - paper.

text.p: Compuware Corp chairman and chief executive Peter Karmanos, may bring up to 1,500 high-technology jobs to the Hartford area, the Hartford Courant reported on Monday.

The paper quoted Karmanos, who also owns the National Hockey League Hartford Whalers, denying any link between the possible new jobs and Karmanos' efforts to get Connecticut to finance a new sports arena for the team.
The Whalers have said they will leave Connecticut unless the state helps build a new arena that could cost around $160 million.
Connecticut Governor John Rowland, a Republican, is expected to announce soon whether he will support a state-financed arena.
"Whether the Whalers stay or not, I view the Hartford area as a prime spot for one of our development labs," Karmanos said.
"We'd like to pursue that independently of what goes on with the Whalers," he said.
Compuware, based in Farmington Hills, Michigan, has about 5,000 employees.
Since its founding in 1973, it has been the dominant supplier of software for testing, debugging and maintaining large mainframe computer systems.
More recently, the company has grown in professional services, including helping corporations deal with updating computer systems to deal with the year 2000, or fighting the so-called millenium bug.
